DOC.HEAD: Vatican Dilemma: What To Do With Noriega
DOC.TEXT: While it's not the first time a political figure has sought refuge in a Vatican embassy, Roman Catholic officials faced a unique dilemma when Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega showed up at the papal nunciate in Panama. Helping the strongman flee the country would likely pique the United States, which invaded Panama last week to try to capture the strongman and bring him to trial on drug charges. At the same time, the Vatican would not be eager to hand him over to U.S. authorities for fear of appearing to condone the invasion and take sides in an international dispute. ``It's a very complex problem,'' said a senior Vatican official early today after learning that Noriega took refuge Sunday at the papal nunciate, or Vatican embassy, in Panama City. The official, who works in foreign policy issues and spoke under the usual ground rule of anonymity, noted that the Vatican has no tradition or policy of accepting asylum seekers. ``The Vatican policy is `we're not open to taking people, we can't take them back to the Vatican.' The Vatican needs to negotiate with a third government to take them. This is much more difficult,'' the official said. The official said the Vatican mission could seek to turn Noriega over to the new Panama government or to arrange for safe passage to another country. ``I don't think they could directly hand Noriega over to the Americans, who are an invading army,'' the official said. ``They would be recognizing the Americans as the local authorities. Instead, they could hand him over to the government there on condition of a fair trial.'' The official said Noriega may have chosen to take refuge at the Vatican embassy because he feels it offers the most guarantees and is the one mission whose diplomatic immunity the United States would not want to violate. Just two months ago, the Vatican embassy in Panama had sheltered opposition leader Guillermo Endara after he was beaten by Noriega's soldiers. Endara was later installed as president after the U.S. invasion. In 1983, four Marxist guerrillas sought refuge at the Vatican mission in Santiago, Chile, after they were accused by Chilean authorities in the assassination of retired Army Gen. Carol Urzua, the governor of metropolitan Santiago. The Holy See arranged for their safe conduct out of the country on grounds they would have faced summary judgment in Chile by an army war tribunal. Another case of political refuge involving the Vatican was that of the late Hungarian Cardinal Josef Mindszenty, who was convicted of treason in 1949 in what was widely regarded as a rigged trial. Mindszenty was freed from prison by Hungarian revolutionaries in 1956 and took refuge in the U.S. mission in Budapest when Soviet tanks crushed the uprising. He left his asylum in 1971 under an agreement with the Vatican and died in Vienna in 1975. Pope John Paul II and the local Roman Catholic Church have expressed concern about the U.S. military intervention in Panama. On Friday, the pope said ``there have been clashes with innocent victims and grave discomforts to the population.''
